Portal Audience Erik Wilde: Governance and Platform

(4) Inside-Out: External API Consumers

  • The origin of the term API as we use it today
  • Partners: Driving your business by scaling partnerships (think eBay [Strategy and Business Alignment; The Five Billion Dollar API (1)])
  • Customers: Driving your business by digitizing customer interactions
  • Portals are outward-facing and should be business-case centered


Portal Audience Erik Wilde: Governance and Platform

(5) Inside-In: Internal API Platform

  • Driven by the need to decrease coupling
  • Driven by the need to increase flow
  • Part of many stories around digital transformation (think Amazon [Strategy and Business Alignment; The 2002 Bezos Mandate (1)])


Portal Audience Erik Wilde: Governance and Platform

(6) Outside-In: Digital Supply Chain Management

  • Currently not the focus of most portal products and strategies
  • Probably a growing area of concern with increasing dependencies and complexity
  • Should become part of the general Platform Engineering [Platform Engineering (1)] approach

The Great Unbundling Erik Wilde: Governance and Platform

(8) API all the Things!

  • Increasing number of API-enabled capabilities
  • Increasing consumption of API-enabled capabilities
  • Increasing complexity of API footprint and requirements
  • One-size-fits-all API management is on its way out


The Great Unbundling Erik Wilde: Governance and Platform

Three Platform Types Erik Wilde: Governance and Platform

(15) Platform Business

  • Connecting producers and consumers
  • Focusing on core interactions between producers and consumers
  • Potential for rapid growth
  • Many of the world's largest organizations


Three Platform Types Erik Wilde: Governance and Platform

(16) Linear Business Model



Three Platform Types Erik Wilde: Governance and Platform

(17) Platform Business Model



Three Platform Types Erik Wilde: Governance and Platform

(18) Hybrid Business Model



Three Platform Types Erik Wilde: Governance and Platform

(19) API Platform

  • Invented 2000 based on SOAP/XML/HTTP (Salesforce, eBay, Amazon)
  • APIs as a way to digitally connect with partners
  • Extended to the idea of platforms as team interfaces (The 2002 Bezos Mandate [Strategy and Business Alignment; The 2002 Bezos Mandate (1)])
  • Some API platforms decide to supports SDKs for easier consumption


Three Platform Types Erik Wilde: Governance and Platform

(20) Developer Platform

  • API Platform [API Platform (1)] but probably a different set of APIs
  • Support for specific consumption (beyond generic SDKs)
  • Support for API production (think Bezos Mandate [Strategy and Business Alignment; The 2002 Bezos Mandate (1)])
  • Many organizations now have/create specific platform teams

Typical API Journey Erik Wilde: Governance and Platform

(22) From Experimentation to Scaling

  1. Trying to increase speed by decreasing coupling: Initial APIs
  2. Increasing number of APIs and increasing use of 3rd party APIs
  3. Fear and loathing because optimizing decentralized landscapes works differently
  4. Programs emerge that help teams and introduce governance structures
  5. Strategies are defined that provide directions and set goals


Typical API Journey Erik Wilde: Governance and Platform

Exercise #3: Platform Strategy Erik Wilde: Governance and Platform

(32) Growing Your Platform

  • Teams are spending too much time reinventing the wheel
  • Teams spend too much time repeating tasks (same team or across teams)
  • Decentralization is creating issues that need addressing

Guidelines Erik Wilde: Governance and Platform

(34) API Guidelines as Shared Practices

  • More API teams mean more ways to solve the same problem
    • Solving API problems is not what teams should focus on
    • Solving API problems in a consistent way helps the API landscape
  • Communications across teams is a challenge
    • Complement channels with documentation of practices


Guidelines Erik Wilde: Governance and Platform

(35) The Anatomy of a Good Guideline

  • Why does the guideline exist?
    • Rationale for creating the guideline
  • What can be done to address the described issue
    • At least one good solution for addressing the issue
  • How to implement the solution
    • At least one way to use the solution in practice
  • Testing that the guideline has been followed
    • Some tests can be automated but many will be by declaration or review


Guidelines Erik Wilde: Governance and Platform

(36) API Guideline Example



Guidelines Erik Wilde: Governance and Platform

(37) Good is better than Best

  • Solutions (What) are addressing design challenges
    • Have a model for accepting new solutions
  • Practices (How) are implementing a solution
    • Have a model for accepting new practices


Guidelines Erik Wilde: Governance and Platform

(38) Good Guideline Management

  • Guidelines should be managed in a participatory way
    • Guidelines are for capturing and sharing experiences across API teams
    • Everybody can comment or contribute to the guidelines
    • Over time it may make sense to develop a more formal approval process
    • There may be editors but their role is to improve guideline quality
  • Tooling should reflect the nature as a living document
    • One-way tooling is a bad choice
    • Collaborative tooling is a good choice


Guidelines Erik Wilde: Governance and Platform

(39) API Guidelines in the Wild



Guidelines Erik Wilde: Governance and Platform

(40) Getting Started

  • Start capturing feedback from API teams
    • Challenges along the way
    • Solutions they have found or implemented
    • Quantifying the time they spend with cross-cutting vs. domain tasks
  • Start editing and providing guidance that API teams can find and use
    • Tooling can be as simple as markdown and shared repositories
  • Treat your API Guidelines as a product
    • There are well-defined user stories as well as goals and non-goals
    • There is clear ownership of the product (which is different from the content)
  • Good guidelines result in better APIs and faster API teams
